I am assuming that Russia will be fully engaged in Syria for the next 4 months. I am not sure if a clash between Russia and NATO countries forces in Syria would meet the criteria for Article 4 as it would presumably not threaten the Territorial Integrity, Political Independence or Security of any NATO country. 
Its possible that Russia could provoke an incident somewhere else, possibly in the period after US elections and the new US President taking office, if it thought that the US might be slow to react, with the aim to have occupied some territory before NATO reacted. It is possible that Russia might provoke an incident in order to get a reaction from the US that might affect the US elections. (e.g. create an incident in Transnistria that threatened Moldova and Romania, Romania being in NATO, hoping to stir up rhetoric that would improve Trump's chances of getting elected, which Putin sees as being to his advantage. 
But none of these possibilities seems very likely.

Sitrep Stratfor Inc (c 2016)
September 22, 2016 | 12:53 GMT
A Turkish presidential spokesman reiterated on Sept. 22 that Turkish forces would not participate in a coalition offensive to retake the Islamic State's de facto capital of Raqqa if Kurdish fighters are involved, Reuters reported. Turkey considers U.S.-backed People's Protection Units (YPG) to be terrorists connected to Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) insurgents who operate inside Turkey. The spokesman's statement comes the day after news broke that the White House is considering directly arming YPG fighters for the first time, as reported by the New York Times. The move is representative of the tightrope the United States has to walk in Syria: The YPG has been one of the most effective forces fighting against the Islamic State, but sending weapons to Kurdish fighters would surely aggravate Turkey.

Article 4 has been invoked 3 times in 2003, twice in 2012, once in 2013, and was discussed in 2014 by Turkey. Given the increased frequency of encounters between Russia and NATO members in recent past, it definitely increases the odds. Given that 2/3 of 2016 being over and a rate of one invocation per year, I'm starting with a 33% approximation. But given the desire of NATO members to avoid conflict (even non-armed conflict), I'm lowering this to 25%.

Since 2012 Article 4 has been invoked 4 times, before that only once, twice in 2012 by Turkey over the Syrian Civil War, after the downing of an unarmed Turkish F-4 reconnaissance jet, and after a mortar was fired at Turkey from Syria; in 2014 by Poland, following the Russian intervention in Crimea; and again by Turkey in 2015 after threats by the Islamic State to its territorial integrity. This means the run rate is about 1 a year recently but hardly ever before. With only a half year to go I calibrate the chance between the recent and the historical run rate

NATO member states that can invoke Article 4 with credibility, based upon geographical proximity to Ukraine, is limited to 4: Poland, Bulgaria, Romania and Turkey. Military personnel (active and reserve) in both Turkey (1m) and Poland (635k) is significant whilst that in Bulgaria (300k) and Romania (150k). The invocation of Article 4 would unlikely be motivated by a genuine military threat against any of these nations by Russia. Instead, it is more likely that Article 4, which triggers a gathering of all NATO member states, would be used to as an opportunity to re-affirm international opinion against Russia's actions in Ukraine and, in doing so, solidify support for the maintenance of the sanctions against Russia. A politically-inspired, rather than militarily motivated invocation, is therefore plausible. NATO website states: "In Article 4 of NATO’s founding treaty, members are encouraged to bring subjects to the table for discussion within the North Atlantic Council, the principal forum for political consultation." (source http://www.nato.int/cps/en/natolive/topics_49187.htm). Though article 4 has only been invoked 5 times since the creation of NATO, it has been used twice recently by both Poland (in 2014 concerning Russia) and Turkey (in 2015 regarding Syria). As an outside bet, Ukraine itself could potentially become a NATO member (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Individual_Partnership_Action_Plan) and therefore invoke article 4 however the timetable for membership almost certainly extends beyond 1 Jan 2017. The recent visit to Kyiv by the NATO Secretary General, during which agreements were signed to formalise the NATO’s diplomatic representation in Ukraine, to support communications, and to strengthen technical cooperation on defence highlights the desire to bring Ukraine on board.
